CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 18, 1949, p. 4, reads: "Accused Policemen Cleared by Trial Board -Tailor Talks Withdrawal with Attorney...Theron B. Hamilton, member of the Business and Professional Association, is pictured chatting with Clark Watts, Tuesday noon shortly after Mr. Watts had presented an affidavit stating his desire to withdraw charges made by him against officers Karl Jackson and John Hicks. Mr.  Hamilton and Samuel Scott were members of two-man committee appointed to assist Mr. Watts in preparing to withdraw charges following meeting, Monday, with BPA.  Trial was held despite Watts' effort to withdraw. - Harris Photo."  Portion of accompanying article reads: "Clark Watts Denies Politics Influenced Filing of Charges - Witnesses of All Races Crowd Trial Room; Wait Throughout Five-Hour Session to Defend Character of Officers Jackson and Hicks - 'Big Brass' of the city's police department, headed by Col. George E. A. Fairley, director of public safety, heard a public airing. Wednesday, of charges that two Hill District police officers were 'aiding and abetting hoodlumism' against a legitimate businessman whom they had allegedly tried to force into the rackets.  The hearing, attended my more than fifty Herron Avenue district businessmen and citizens brought together for the first time Officers Karl C. [O.] Jackson and John Hicks, and their accuser, Clark Watts.  Mrs. Watts is the owner of the Watts' Brothers Cleaner Shop, 2931 Wylie Avenue, an establishment he claimed was coveted by the officers who wished to use it for illegal and illicit purposes..."
TitMainTitle: Atty. Theron B. Hamilton and tailor Clark Watts seated in front of sewing machine in Watt's Brothers Cleaner Shop, 2931 Wylie Avenue, Hill District
